ex:ekiri-1 ekɨrɨ ru man ero-aŋ tɨ-mami-n ɨna
‘The old man went to his work,’

ex:ekiri-2 j-uwj-aŋ man tɨ-wɨ-n
‘He looked for his machete.’

ex:ekiri-3 ɨ-wɨ-n mun eto an-k-aŋ man
‘“Where might my machete be?”, he asked.’

ex:ekiri-4 rɨk rɨk rɨk j-uwi-tk-aŋ man
‘So he went looking for it.’

ex:ekiri-5 pat͡ʃaŋ orotpot-aŋ man owro warakt͡ʃi
‘He went back into the house.’

ex:ekiri-6 m-eneŋ pajŋ ɨ-wɨ-n
‘“Have you seen my machete, dear?”’

ex:ekiri-7 an-k-aŋ man tɨ-muje na
‘He said to his wife.’

ex:ekiri-8 j-apta-gwam t͡ʃutke-rem j-uwɨ-n
‘His machete was under his arm.’

ex:ekiri-9 otumunto mun eto ɨ-wɨ-n otumunto
‘“Where might my machete be, where?”’

ex:ekiri-10 nen-to nen-to j-eŋ-lɨ ɨ-wɨ-n
‘“Here, here I put my machete.”’

ex:ekiri-11 an-k-aŋ man i-mu-n
‘His son said:’

ex:ekiri-12 pupa mun-tu mun w-apta-gwam keni o-wɨ-n
‘“Father, your machete is the one under your arm.”’

ex:ekiri-13 nen tan nen ɨ-wɨ-n
‘“My machete is here.”’

ex:ekiri-14 tɨmo-ŋmo arawɨ-rem-kom an-k-aŋ-tom man i-mu-n emt͡ʃi-n e-muje keni niŋkɨn e-mnop-towo=ge kɨkɨkɨ an-k-aŋ-tom man
‘His family, his son, his daughter, his wife started laughing (because of all this). Hahaha! They laughed.’

ex:tri-1 pai i-wae t-ee-se wïraapa
‘The bow was stronger than the tapir.’
